In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Sure, you can write this function in Julia as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return replace(replace(lowercase(strip(col)), " " => "_"), "-" => "_")
end
```
This function will strip any leading or trailing whitespaces from the input column name (`col`), convert it to lower case and then replace all spaces with underscores. The `replace()` function is used in Julia to replace substrings, firstly replacing all hyphens with underscore and secondly converting all spaces to underscore.

Let's test our function:
```julia
println(clean_column("My Column"))  # Output should be "my_column"
println(clean_column("Your DataFrame"))  # Output should be "your_dataframe"
```
